question: Find the cross product of $\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\begin{pmatrix} 3 \\ 4 \\ -5 \end{pmatrix}.$
answer:
The cross product of $\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\begin{pmatrix} 3 \\ 4 \\ -5 \end{pmatrix}$ is
\[\begin{pmatrix} (-1)(-5) - (4)(2) \\ (2)(3) - (-5)(1) \\ (1)(4) - (3)(-1) \end{pmatrix} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} -3 \\ 11 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix}}.\]
agents_response:
To compute the cross product of two vectors $\begin{pmatrix} a1 \\ a2 \\ a3 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\begin{pmatrix} b1 \\ b2 \\ b3 \end{pmatrix},$ we use the formula 

$\begin{pmatrix} a2*b3 - a3*b2 \\ a3*b1 - a1*b3 \\ a1*b2 - a2*b1 \end{pmatrix}.$ 

For $\begin{pmatrix} a1 \\ a2 \\ a3 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix},$ and $\begin{pmatrix} b1 \\ b2 \\ b3 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 3 \\ 4 \\ -5 \end{pmatrix},$ the cross product is 

$\begin{pmatrix} -1*(-5) - 2*4 \\ 2*3 - 1*(-5) \\ 1*4 - (-1)*3 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 5 - 8 \\ 6 + 5 \\ 4 + 3 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -3 \\ 11 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix}.$ 

So, the answer to the problem is $\boxed{\begin{pmatrix} -3 \\ 11 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix}}.$
